response.answer_text: I have to agree with everyone else here - writers write, and they write a lot. Steven King said in his book On Writing a healthy number is 1,000 - 2,000 words a day. Jack London supposedly wouldn’t start his day until he wrote 1,000 words. (Also, a lot of writers, and the company Google, seem to think that the morning is the best time to be creative). But I’m going out on a limb here and thinking that this question is really about how do you work as a writer. As in, get paid to write. Which is a much, much more difficult question. For my part, I’ve only gotten paid to write for magazines, blogs, and news sites (and very occasionally, a comic script or a web short). I am no success. So, most of what I know about the subject comes from reading about the paths better writers have taken. And cribbing from a few people I know who could call themselves vaguely successful. But the first thing is, what kind of writer? Nonfiction magazines, trade publications, etc.? Start by figuring out what you know well, or what you wouldn’t hate to research. Typically, the most technical expertise required, the better the pay. Then, before you start writing, read some of those magazines. Not just any, the ones who might take a submission. There’s Writer’s Digest’s Writers Market 2018 for that, or this handy database: Freelance Rates Database Be creative about the niche (you’d be amazed how many bloggers make a living by writing about Disneyland). Journalism? Good luck. The process is similar, but arguably more difficult. Publications like the Washington Post, and the Guardian take freelance contributions, but you’d better be good to get in. A lot of the contributors are bona fide experts in something; they have something to say. It’ll be easier (maybe) to go more local, but the news paper business is drying up fast, and even a small established publications can ask for long resumes as more seasoned journalists go looking for jobs. Screenwriter? Write something, then see if you can get a little piece of it made and send it around. This seems to work well for animated shows - South Park was a brief Christmas card, Rick and Morty was a short parody of Back to the Future. If you don’t have some friends with cameras, or who can draw, then try Black List and see if a reviewer likes it. It costs a little, but great things have come from that site. There are also agents you can send scripts too, but there’s a little Chicken or the Egg problem there. A lot of agents don’t seem willing to take a chance on someone not already established… and then you’re counting on an agent to get established. Short Stories? Good luck. Literary Magazines increasingly seem to be on one pole or the other. Either incredibly high-quality with virtually no chance of an amateur succeeding (The New Yorker) or partial scams that depend more on charging authors reading fees than selling their magazines. Here’s a little of the high end: Top 50 Literary Magazines -Every Writer - Every Writer There are also contests - 31 Free Writing Contests: Legitimate Competitions With Cash Prizes Same problem with contests about the reading fees. Novels? ??? A lot of people claim you should just publish yourself, either for eReaders like Kindle, or with real books using something like CreateSpace. It’s easy… real easy. So easy, that everyone has done it. The explosion of published work has created fun little statistics. As of 2011, if you read one book a day, every day, it would take you 60,000 years to read every book registered with the Library of Congress. I’m sure that number is much higher now. Real publishers still exist. Many are scams or vanity publishers, asking you to pay the publishing costs and selling almost exclusively to friends and family members of the author. Some are real, and very difficult to sell to. Once again - Chicken or the Egg. Big publishers want big names. To get a big name you need a good publisher… sometimes. For all of these, there are some bits that are a little more universal: Know you genre/niche/expertise well. Read thoroughly in he area you’re going into. Reading might be more important than writing really.Build an audience. Some people are great in short form - so they master Twitter. Then when the time is right, they publish something for their fans and start making money. Others are great on Reddit. Others try on Quora…Avoid the scams and reading fees (unless you can really really verify its authenticity. There are some good ones, like Black List). Anything that shows a writer on the beach with a laptop, who happens to be a beautiful woman, is generally a scam.Figure out the schedule. Here’s the daily routine of a bunch creative geniuses (including writers): Creative Routines. As Terry Pratchett said, “Only in our dreams are we free. The rest of the time we need wages.” Meaning that while you’re trying to make it, you’ll need to work. You might make a full-time income writing blogs, shorts and news articles, then one day, the ad rates go down… less people seem to read… the freelance offers seem to be lacking… and then you might end up driving Lyft for a while. It happens, just keep writing.I guess the biggie is to write… there’s that too.

Well, what is it that you think writers do? They write! Of course.  "There is nothing to writing. All you do is sit down and bleed." – Ernest Hemingway Some writers write long form, some write short. Some write poems, others write biographies. Some went through years of schooling to learn what it means to write well, others simply wrote and wrote and wrote until readers started to pay attention. If you want to be a writer, the most sure-fire way to do it is to 1) find something to write about, 2) write about it, 3) find a way to share what you wrote with the world. Thankfully the Internet has made much of this process easier than ever! The only thing technology won't do for you is the actual writing. Which is what writers do, so you'll have to look into that bit a little more. But on the other two points: the finding something to wring about and sharing what you write, you can turn to the Internet (which it appears is exactly what you've done here). Finding what to write about What to write about? I don't think it matters much what your topic or style of writing is, only that you're passionate about them equally. You can be passionate about automobiles, but unless you're equally passionate about writing about automobiles, you're going to find yourself flubbing about a lot when the time to write comes. We call these people "aspiring writers" because they want to be writers and they are excited about a topic, but they cannot — for their lives — sit down and actually write. Explore what other people have written about, think of anything you've read that sparked a particular interest in you or that captured your attention so completely. Writing isn't difficult, you'll find. I mean, it can be difficult to get yourself to set up your computer or type writer or papers just write, to pour the ideal amount of coffee or tea into a mug, to will your butt onto the chair and, as Hemingway famously quipped, bleed. But oh what a chore finding something you actually give two cents worth of interest about can be! It's not the actual sitting down to putting the words together that is particularly difficult. Toddlers do it! Finding something you can dedicate many of your limited heartbeats toward expressing, something you can transform from that intangible nothingness that exists only inside your head into something that others can feel and see and taste and hear and be part of...all from a few lines and dots on a page? That's where the work comes in. But don't let that statement scare you away! Anyone can be a writer, a good writer at that, if they take the time to put their heart into writing. That's really all there is too it. Once you've got that down you must then find someone who is willing to read what you've written. Find an audience Start a blog. Share snippets of your writing on social media sites like Facebook or Twitter. H Publish the book yourself and see if any local, small bookshops would be interested in selling it. Do whatever it takes to get the word out, literally. If you want to be a writer — really, truly — then simply write. If you want to be a great writer, just keep writing. I don't believe you need to get formal training or to become a student at a notable institute to do what anyone with enough heart, energy, and a pad of paper can do, let alone do it well.

The simplest answer is to write and publish a book.  At the lowest level of the equation, you can write something and publish it on Amazon Kindle or Smashwords or Create Space or some other platform and "Presto!"  you're an author.  Whether or not what you've written is utter dreck that nobody, even your mom will bother reading, you are an author.  Congratulations. Right, that was a snide answer, but millions of people each year pick that path and declare to anyone who'll listen, that they're an author.  The other answer is that you sit down and spend months, if not years, writing something and making it something that doesn't just please yourself, but also pleases others who read it.  This is a very difficult path, and in all honesty, I'm not sure it's really a path worth following.  The publishing business is really pretty crappy and the agents and editors that you're forced to suck up to are, by and large, a pretty rum bunch.  The book publishing and distribution business is ineptly run and ridden with gatekeepers who decide whether to put a book on bookstore bookshelves based on weird, capricious, whims.   If you choose to go this route, it is almost guaranteed heartbreak.   But that's how you get readers.  And you will be an Author and nobody can ever dispute this fact.  If you choose self-publishing, people hearing you call yourself an author will inevitably roll their eyes and say "Okayyyyyy!"  But you know what's funny about this whole silly business.  The process of finding readers is exactly the same regardless of which route you pick. You're going to have to beat the bushes for readers either way.  Believe me, New York publishers will do only the most pro-forma promotion and marketing for you.  You'll have to promote your book yourself and if you're really good, you can find as many readers with a self-published book as with a commercially published one.   Of course if it's legitimacy you want,  there's only one way to do it.

I love to write, whether it’s working on my next serial, making a blog post, or answering questions here on Quora, I love it.  So, you want to be a writer. Your first step? Just start writing. It really is that simple. But, beyond that, here are my thoughts on how you can get that career, if that’s what you’re after, off the ground. Read. Yep, you heard me right. You cannot be a good writer if you don’t read a lot. You must scower your particular genre (the one you’d like to write in) and read, read, read. Read the best-sellers. Read the books/publications that aren’t doing so hot. Read the reviews of what you read. This will give you a great idea of what is selling and what readers want/don’t like.Get a tough editor. I say get an editor, but just get someone that is a grammar cop in their spare time, or someone that you know LOVES your genre. You want someone that is tough to point out issues with your writing. Don’t see these critiques as failure, but see them as opportunities to grow better at your craft.Keep a notebook or journal by your bed. You never know when an idea will come to you… might be in the middle of the night! Write these down.Study people and take notes. (If you’re writing fiction, that is) One of my favorite things to do is to people watch. Waiting for a flight is the best time, in my opinion. You see so many different people from all walks of life in an airport. (Like Lord Vader and his minions below) Write.Just like everything in life, you can’t expect to be great at it the first, second, or fiftieth try… but hang in there. If you love what you are doing and love what you are writing, you can do it. :)

One does not simply become an author, yes it can be a "thing" or one can "be" and author, but it's not something you achieve but are born to be. It is a way of life.  To be an author; it means having something inside your head just dying to get out. It’s a beautiful magic creation that you feel you must put down on paper for the world to see. You will spend years chasing it, and countless hours going out of your mind to perfect it. It means to touch people on a deeper level just by writing words. To make them able to see what you are saying. To achieve greatness when they can feel, taste, and smell what you are writing. It means to weave amazing pictures in the readers mind. Bright vivid pictures with realistic sounding people. It means to pull a character out of a book and sit them right beside you. It means to ponder and think then to think and rethink again. It means your time is never your own. It means that you are a slave to the words bursting forth from your mind. There will be days when you will pray for words and others when you wish they would stop. It means when the words start coming, you must drop what ever you are doing to write them down before losing them forever. Being a author means being able to look at things in a strange way that others may not understand. It means to think outside the box, and to walk the fine line between strange and insane. It means that some people might call you crazy, And maybe you are, maybe to be a author means to be crazy. For those of us who write, to be a author simply means living and breathing life in your own special way.

I apologize, but before I start, I have to do this: *writer. Alright, so the steps to becoming a writer are so hard and dangerous, and you cannot possibly begin with something costly and difficult to find. Many dragons need to be slain, so we need something mightier than even the finest of enchanted swords. No, my friend, we need… A Pen! Or a computer. Okay, so here’s what you do: Write! Write anything. It’ll all suck at first, no one starts amazing. Look up some prompts, and write as often as you can. If you do that, within under a year, you’ll go from a beginning writer who’s not great to someone who can at least make a good storyline! I will, however give you these tips, which were learned over about 3 years of serious writing, and while they sound dumb, if you start with these tips, you might get better faster! Actually plan out the story.There were at least 7 stories I started and couldn’t finish, and as I got towards the middle of the story, I couldn’t figure out where to go. Why? Because I didn’t plan it. I had a vague concept, made up some names, and started writing. That’s okay, up until the time when you actually want to finish the story. What you want to do, when planning, is give your concept, first. Then expand upon it a bit. Actually, as much as you can. Now that you have the idea of how the story is supposed to go, you can either start writing and plan as you go, or get even more in detail, and plan out the first however much of the story you want. It’s up to you to write it well when it comes time, and for the outline, you can skimp on detail. Then, if the story takes on a path of its own, you can afford to be flexible. Actually create your characters.Now that you know what your story is, create your characters. Their personalities should add something to the story and contribute to the plot. For example, Charlotte’s Web wouldn’t have worked if Fern was a sadistic girl who didn’t care much for animals. So especially for your main characters (protagonists, antagonists, best friends in either direction), make sure it fits the story, or expect the plot to drift a bit. Write as often as possible, and when you have to stop for a while, don’t write everything you have in mind.Seems counterintuitive. “I have to go to bed, though, so shouldn’t I finish this idea first?” No. Okay so think of this: It’s so easy to get started when you have an idea, isn’t it? Like, when you’re falling asleep and you think of something great so you jot it down and then use it the next morning. So when you have to sleep or go somewhere, write down some small reminder or brief summary of the idea, or the next part, etc., and then when you come back, you have that to jump-start you back into the story, whereas if you wrote everything, you’d have to spend another 15 minutes, probably, thinking of the next part. Of course, the outline should help, but still. It makes things easier, and plus, you won’t spend all night going “just 5 more minutes”. And by writing as much as you can, not only does it create an okay habit, but it also helps you get good at it as fast as possible. Following the tips, or not, this will help you get better at writing. In Conclusion, just remember that nearly anyone can write, but it does take time to become a good writer.

If you are new to writing, please oh please do not be discouraged by the first few attempts, no matter what genre you chose, if you’re going for technical or creative. I believe the first step definitely would be to decide what you want to write about, what you want to say and who your intended audience will be. For now don’t duel on the impact your writing should have or whether it is good. If you’re starting out, I would suggest you pick a topic and start writing snippets in the form of your choice; i.e. short stories, poems etc. How to go about it will greatly depend on your personal choices. There are those who can simply start writing, and there are those who need to have every little sequence of event pre-planned. Perhaps an outline is beneficial for you, especially if you are taking on a novel form which are more complex and tend to have subplots… see where I’m going with this? I taught myself to write. It was a pain in the butt because I didn’t have any guidance such as writing clubs. So I made many mistakes. One of the pitfalls of starting out is that you will notice that you start to improve your writing skills. Narrative becomes more coherent, scenes begin to flow, etc. BUT, no matter how tempted you are, DO NOT stop to edit!!! I made that mistake many many many times simply because I realized that my previous scenes were not at the height as the later ones. So I kept rewriting and rewriting and it took me forever to finish my story. Let me tell you a little anecdote about how I started and the mistakes mentioned above. I set out to write a short story meant to be open ended to hopefully encourage the reader to fill the blanks of subsequent possible events that would never be. I get a little satisfaction on that hehehe… don’t mind me… back on track. So, being the creative person I am, while writing this simple piece in short story form so as to not have to duel on the heavy details that are an inevitable part of the novel form, I realized that my brain had set flight. I soon began to expand the story in my mind, imagining possibilities after possibilities of plot developments… and then and there I decided I would make this short story the full blown novel it is today. Let me tell you that the decision did not come without its fear factors. I had never attempted a novel before and I knew the road would be a difficult one in my case since I had no support whatsoever. So I read a few book on the subject of writing fiction and creative writing. Save yourself the trouble. While they do have good advise here and there, there is no specific answer as to how to write. The common theme in books on how to write is that you practice and continue practicing. So I decided that the short story I wrote needed to be converted into novel form. I tinkerered and worked on it day in and day out. At first it was infuriating because I foolishly expected quick results. That is not how this works. Soon, as the novel progressed and I reached the end of my first chapter, WOW!!! That feeling will stay with you forever. So I used that adrenaline height and pushed on to the second chapter. Here I began to note an improvement in my narratives, and thus the mistake of stopping to auto edit myself to try to bring the previous chapter to par. Whatever you do, do not make the mistakes I made. Look at the exercise for what it is, a practice in the form of a draft that is yours and only yours. Do not put pressure on yourself thinking you must finish in a week. It will take time. Trust me when I tell you that you will laugh and you will cry as you attempt, fail, attempt again until you succeed. Because when you do succeed you will learn that you have an ability not many have. Realizing that you can do it is something that will inspire you to go on and on. Don’t be deterred by the early results. Nothing is ever created or developed overnight. There will be a process of trial and error very normal when developing new skills. Keep at it. You will make it, just as I did. If you go the route of more complex writing such as novel or technical form, and you feel an outline is your thing, you might want to check out existing softwares aimed to do just that. An example is Dramatica Pro. However, never let these softwares dictate the route your story should go. You are the writer, you are the author and you should decide where your story goes. Hope this answer helps. Write on!!!!

Well it takes a lot. I'll summarise the best I can. Although most of my views will be regarding novel/story writing they may (or may not) apply to other writings as well. Here goes: It takes a very healthy imagination. While writing you will come across times where you will be blocked and you won't know what to do next. This is what writers call Grey Area. This is where your imagination will help you the most. And also imagination is indeed the driving force of any type of literature.You need to read. Read a lot! Read whatever you can, whenever you can. “If you don't have the time to Read, you don't have the skill (tools) to write.”— Stephen King.You need perseverance and tolerance. Writing is no easy task. You will have good days and bad days. Live with it. And don't let go. “ There is nothing to writing. All you have to do is sit at a typewriter and bleed.”— Ernest Hemingway.Writing needs a deep understanding of nature and human behaviour. You need to be observant.You need to understand that your writing venture is not going to be a cake walk. It's a lot tougher than it looks.You should practice and hone your writing skills daily. Can turn out to be boring at times but it is utmost necessary.“The first draft of anything is shit.” — Ernest Hemingway. This is very important. It may look like shit but you need to revise and write and rewrite it until it becomes you masterpiece.I'll add more point if I coke across them during my writing sessions. By that time, Go Write! Suggestions are welcome. Happy Writing.

Understand first that no two writers will create the same way. Dispense with the idea “if I do it the way he does it I will succeed.” Start by putting one word after another. Use nouns. Verbs. Other stuff. Throw in an idea. Create a character and give her/him a challenge. Make another character a bad guy. Before you know it you have a story. Or write a thought. An idea. The way the light catches all the detail of a flower. Listen to other writers speak. Read all the time. Listen to yourself think, then write it down. Recollect the past in the tranquility of the present, a la Walt Whitman, and write. Music—with or without lyrics—will often push your fingers on the keyboard or a pen across paper. Let yourself live. Do something every day that you’ve never done before, even if it’s simply to try a new flavor. Talk to people about ideas. Don’t waste your time around people you don’t respect. Enter the library at least once a month and rummage around. Talk to small children about their ideas. …after you do all these things, carve out the time to isolate yourself and watch the words flow across the screen or the page. Repeat above steps. Good luck.

Good question! First, you have to come up with fresh idea. Start reading good fiction novels, carry paperback books with you, read all the time for inspiration. Carry a notebook and write down any and all ideas that come to mind.Once you’ve got something interesting, write down a treatment for it, create a quick beginning, middle, and end. Remember, good books/movies are kind of like good jokes: You’ve got to know your punchline before you start telling the story.After you’ve devised the plot and characters, start writing. If you’ve never written a book or a movie and have no idea how to write, google it and study until you get the basics, then WRITE, WRITE, and REWRITE.If you’re writing a movie, then keep your story’s setting limited to two or three locations. Shoot your movie with your friends, finish it and show it to everyone. If you’ve never written a book or a feature length film, then you probably are a terrible writer right now and you need tons of practice — even if you have written a book or a movie, it’s probably poorly constructed. I’m trying to save you the rejection heartbreak you will receive once you try to peddle your script to anyone in a Hollywood. Best bet is to work on one script for at least a year, reworking it until it’s decent. Writing is not so much a gift, as it is a job. Treat it like a 9 to 5.

I assume you know how to read, well, then read! Read mostly the genre that you are planning to write in — fiction, poetry, nonfiction, drama, etc. Then write! Write and rewrite and revise and rewrite again. Consult an editor when you have a “work” written and been rewritten to your satisfaction. Send it out for publication (Good luck!). Accept rejections gleefully and try to rewrite and improve. Remember writing is a process that rewires your brain. You have to grow with your writing and the other way around. Join a book discussion group or a writers’ group but don’t make it a religion. Stick to your style and guns. Say what you want to say and say it as simply and as forcefully as possible. It helps if it is beautiful too. When you have enough successes in publications, get a literary agent to represent your work (Good luck!). Don’t give up. You got to think and feel and suffer, there is no other way. Never lose sight of humanity. If humanity is not there, your writing will never matter. Try to think about the world but also remember that literature lasts longer than this generation, what is in the marketplace, who is the President of the land, etc. They are important like the price of food is also. But to be a writer is to be always hungry, not so much to be recognized as a good writer or a genius, but the hunger to be known by another human being. You might write something that is as perishable as lettuce or as enduring as the Great Wall of China. In any case, “measure your progress by how long it takes you to get there.” Oh, by the way, you will need a job other than that of a writer. I am still trying to sucker people to publish with my press Goldfish Press.

Becoming an author is as much a balance of self as it is a system of effort and sacrifice. Obviously a great deal of the process relies on one's dedication to the writing process, but there comes the time when a writer must take the step from a private scribe to a potentially public figure. A wise mentor of mine once said that a writer becomes an author when they find that writing is only half of being an author, and while writing is undeniably an inescapable step in the process it's true that a writer who never submits their work can never advance. There are a number of options in this second step, but for the purpose of simplicity it's best to view it as a choice between three distinct paths: self, indie, & traditional. Self - despite what many say, self publishing is not an ugly word and there is no shame in doing so (while it stands to reason that self publishing is the "easiest" way to get a piece out, if it is of low quality or sub-standard effort then the piece will not go far and, worse yet, the public that is reached can--and often does--do substantial damage with poor reviews and word of mouth). While self publishing can be an unforgiving crash course in what it's like to be in the public eye when one is not ready (it's been said that every rejection letter is easier to swallow then another reader pointing out you weren't ready to see print), many well-written authors see monumental success in this process. Because self-publishing puts near-total (if not total) control of every element of how the piece goes out (including cover art, internal formatting, networking platforms, etc...), then somebody who is well versed--or has connections who are well versed--in the various arenas can see the release of a compelling piece that will earn them 100% of the earnings. Indie publishers - This process represents a "cool center". Though self publishing represents a form of indie publishing, there are publishers who operate in this realm. These publishers are less dictated by the confines of commercial publishing and, as a result, more author-friendly (I've heard horror stories of traditional authors submitting a completed manuscript to their publisher only to be told that they need to completely rewrite the piece in order to incorporate a "crowd-pleasing" element to cater to the publisher's demographic; regardless of what those changes mean to for the piece). The submission process varies for indie publishers (they'll often specify their guidelines; for example, my company, Tiger Dynasty Publishing, has a guidelines page that mirrors the standard formatting guidelines of traditional publishers that can be found at tiger-dynasty.com), and the services provided will vary as well. However, for the most part the general process of going through an indie publisher allows an author a great deal of ease in the publishing process (TDP and others, for example, will provide editing, cover designs, and other publishing costs at no expense to the author), as well as helping to market and promote the piece upon publication. Finally, there's traditional publishing. This is, of course, what most people think of when they consider the process. Many will argue that this is "harder" than other methods, but it stands to reason that, as mentioned earlier, a rejection letter isn't always a symbol of failure, but one of being not yet prepared (the success rate of traditional publishing mirroring the fact that commercial publishers only accept pieces that they personally feel will return the multi-thousand dollar investment an accepted piece represents). However, time, ease of submission (the shift from mailing manuscripts to one of simply emailing a file has made the proverbial "inbox" for publishers substantially more filled each day) and an over-saturation in the market has motivated many publishers closed to what is referred to "unsolicited manuscripts". An unsolicited manuscript is a submission by an author who is not represented by a literary agent, and it has been said that acquiring a literary agent is often more difficult a process than getting the actual publisher. The process of querying an agent isn't altogether uncommon from querying a publisher--it follows the same general premise of "here is my piece and why everyone should love it"--but an agent (at least the honest ones), are more hesitant about accepting due to a number of elements, the most predominant being a preexisting workload with other clients as well as the gamble of representing a piece that might not succeed (a true threat to somebody whose time is directly proportionate to their earnings, especially when their earnings are based on a percentage of the piece's sales ~ usually in the vicinity of 10-15%). Whether or not an agent is involved, an accepted piece through a traditional publisher is often met with an advance (a pre-determined sum of money that represents, as the name would imply, an advance on estimated earnings from the piece; if a publisher offers a $10k advance, they will not begin paying the author royalties from sales until they have sold $10k worth of books). Now, despite what many will say, no one option is "the best" for anybody. Just as every person is unique, every author is an individual, and the personal know-how and strengths will determine which option is best for them. I'm often asked "what did you do?" or "what path would you suggest based on your success?" in regards to my own path as an author, but I rarely offer up solid advice for them in this measure as what I've done does not hold any merit in what would work best for them (though I've never refused an aspiring writer the information they would want/need to make an educated move of their own).

How can I become a writer? I want to write a book, but I don’t know what the first step is. Firstly, the question is slightly baffling. You say that you don’t know what the first steps are, but that you want to become a writer. Simply put: you can’t become a writer without writing; if you aren’t already writing, why do you want to become a writer? How do you know? Anyway, ignoring that for a second, my recommendations would as follows: Find out if you enjoy writing first. Is this something you yearn to do, even if the money isn’t great? Is it something you’re willing to do as a hobby while you also work full-time? Would you go out of your way to find the time to write?Start a few short stories and see what you think. If you’re struggling for ideas, try some of these: Writing Exercises and PromptsMaybe read some writing books or take a course to see what other writers say about form, plotting, character development, beginner mistakes etc. In a way it’s true what they say - you can’t teach writing, but you can learn good practices, what to do, what not to do etc. The same way you teach a sprinter to run fast, but you can teach him the techniques to enable him to run at full capacity.You’re going to need a circle of readers who are willing to give you some honest critiques. And not family either. They will just say, “that’s great, honey” because they don’t want to hurt your feelings. Look around online for people who are willing to critique your writing, or friends, other writing group members - and learn from them.When you feel comfortable enough with your writing, find some short story competitions to enter. Preliminary The first step to good writing is reading. It is 100% necessary to be active and participatory reader before becoming a professional writer. Read good works. Read bad works. Read literary giants. Read tabloids and magazines. Fill your head with written words. Think of writing as using Lego blocks. You are only able to build certain things with certain blocks. There are limits. If for instance you only have square blocks, then you can only make those configurations. There is a reason the more complicated sets of Legos include different shapes and pieces - they offer more potentials. Your words are your blocks. You sentence structures, phrases, metaphors, etc. are never original but pilfered from life experience. The more you collect the more sophisticated your writing can become, and the more options or potentials you have in store for yourself. Once an avid reader, writing because a method of constructing not mimicking. You stop borrowing from source A and B and you start synthesizing to create all sorts of combinations of As and Bs, AAB BAA BBA ABA etc. Train No master comes to her skill without training. Malcolm Gladwell famously said we need 10,000 hours of progressive work to master material. This works out to be about 5 years of 40 hours a week - and that is to attain the mastery of your potential, not the world’s. Meaning, you can play piano at increasingly difficult measures for 5 years, 40 hours a week and never become Mozart, you will simply become the best you can be based on your personal potential. To be a writer, professionally, you need to train. There are many who informally train - they write blogs, enter competitions, attend workshops, write journals etc. But the time commitment is the same. There is formal training such as degree programs or certifications - creative writing, journalism, English, majors etc. at undergraduate and graduate levels. But again, its about time commitment. Informal training works for independent, self-driven and self-motivated people. Formal training offers structure and guidance. Fail Then you have to be willing to fail. I sign my books with this phrase: “Celebrate the times you have failed, and continued to try. Winning is fleeting. Learning from mistakes will last you a lifetime. Go and make as many mistakes as you can.” I queried nearly a hundred agents and publishers before The Marvelous Paracosm of Fitz Faraday and the Shapers of the Id was picked up by a small, independent publisher. As for my nonfiction articles, the same was true. But each time I failed I learned what not to do. Sometimes the hardest part about being a writer is not the writing, but the promoting and the connecting. Onward!

What’s the first step to becoming a writer? You’d think it would be “write”, but it’s not. In speaking to other writers and from what I know of my own journey to becoming a writer, I’ve come to realize that the biggest obstacle for new writers is that they don’t think of themselves as writers. They have trouble developing the belief that they are writers and yet it’s something you have to do. When you haven’t developed that belief, that conviction, it becomes a source of sabotage–you don’t value your work enough to give it the time and the space it needs. How do you come to think of yourself as a writer, especially when you’re not earning a paycheck as a writer? Here are a few tips: What Happens When You Write? If you want to be a writer, I’m assuming you feel you have something to say and a strong desire to say it. You may not know how you’re going to say it or in what form (poetry, novel, essay, etc.) but you know something is there. Okay, you pick up your pencil or pen or you sit down to your computer or typewriter. Write something. Whatever you write, just make sure your heart is in it. It doesn’t have to be perfect, it doesn’t have to be neat. It does have to be expressive. Next, as painful as it may be, you have to show this writing to someone. It can be a friend, it can be a family member. Then, pay attention to what happens. Did the person reading your work cry, laugh or get angry? If so, you did that! It means you can have an effect with your writing. It’s worth something. You have to keep going! A teenager recently wrote to me concerned because she’s writing fiction and she’s worried her mother will read it and get upset because she thinks it’s stuff the teenager really did. On the one hand, that is a bummer to have to explain yourself to your mother, but on the other hand–wow, that means the young lady’s work is believeable and effective. That kind of feedback is hard to ignore. It’s powerful motivation to keep you going–if you take the time to notice and honor that it’s happening. I once had a writer say to me, “I don’t know if my stuff is any good. I just know that when people read it, they cry.” I told her you can’t get a message any clearer than that kind of response. Now she just has to listen to it. Cultivate Silence If you’re having trouble thinking about what it is you have to say, it may help you to spend some time each day in silence. Some writers pray. Some meditate. The idea is to get used to clearing your brain space and tuning in to your inner voice. You’ll also be more aware of those little scraps of possibility floating around in your head that can later grow into big ideas. What Do You Want to Write? Experiment! It’s okay if you don’t know what you want to write about. It may take a long time journaling for you to see what keeps coming up for you. And it may take longer to find the form that fits you best. I went from poetry to essays to long-form letter writing before I settled on fiction. It took me years to do that. It doesn’t mean I won’t do anything else in those genres, but what I’m doing right now just fits. I encourage you to experiment until you find the form that suits your writing best. Continually Remind Yourself You Are a Writer As you develop your belief that you’re a writer, it’s helpful to set up reminders that will jog you back to that brain space that you need to be in to write. When you sit down to write it’s easy to get distracted and starting thinking about doing laundry or what’s for dinner. You’ll want to have something either on your desk or on the wall in front of you that reminds you to get back to work and that you are a writer. It might be your list of values that remind you that writing is a part of who you are. It may be simple words such as CREATE or INSPIRE. Isabel Allende, who writes beautiful, historical novels will sit in her office with photos around her, old photos of people who essentially represent her characters so she’s surrounded by them. That puts her back into the brain space of her book because she is sitting in their world; these people are all around her. What world do you need to be in? The journey you take to get there will be one of many you’ll take as a writer. I hope these ideas will help you take those first steps. What you write–and where you go from here–is entirely up to you. Bon Voyage.

There is no thumb rule to writing a whole book at a time for the first time. Once you do complete a book, that's when you look back at the chaos you left behind and pick up from there. We learn and improve and mature with every page you write. Every twist or maybe a page you write gives you more clarity about where your chapter is headed. The best way would be to first write down a summary of the idea you have in head. Keep it seperate from your actual story but handy so you can look at it time and again to know of you are on track. You can keep updating it as you move along in the story, since you will tend to find new things to improve it as you keep writing and the more you write the better your story gets. Also, on a seperate page like the summary, keep a seperate page to map the characters. It does not need to be complete before you start writing, you can keep adding to it as you go along. This helps because as you get deeper into your story, you may tend to forget to build characters or the fact that they could your story better than you imagined. Having the map in front of you will help you make use of them better. And finally, just write, you may love or you may hate what you write, but at least you haven't lost the idea or sat on it. Once you write it, you have the tempo to move on or you have content you can rework and fix or it helps you know that it may not be needed at all. That is what editing and reworking is all about, but that happens later. You first put ideas to words, let them flow even if disconnected, you can connect them later, but if you lose tempo or forget getting it back won't be easy. Target writing about a page a day (there will be days you can't, but then aiming for it keeps the hunger to write alive) Keeps revisions of your work (you never know you may like an older version better), don't just throw everything way. In the final edit you can pick and scult your story based on everything you need. Noone gets the story right in the first draft. Even experienced writers finish, read, rework, fix, read again, rework again and continue till then finally appreciate the final product. The important thing is to love it yourself. Whether other like it or not comes later. Write for yourself and not for others, that is the only way you can be true to your skill and art. Then leave it to people to decide whether they like it or not. You will have learnt a whole deal lot about writing a book by then.

Thoughts become our actions and intentions, so long long before writing a book we must review our thinking; put it to print; review, reread and edit it for another and another go-then get feedback and editorial support on the way to having anything worth putting in a book that may benefit others and yourself for the effort. I was told once and it stuck: “tight writing is the result of tight thinking!” Have you checked your thinking; really checked it? Have you obtained feedback? We all have a flair or style but if it’s not unusual, interesting, exceptional… it won’t garner much interest, following or reimbursement. Assuming you have a winning flair or style to assist presenting your position-what is your position, point, thesis? There are very very few completely original new ideas that haven’t already been poised and or printed (more likely none;) so your starting point is what? An old idea rewritten? How novel? That may work, sort of!? So where to start? Pick an idea that resonates with you and will be of interest to others. The subject should suit you, not be so far beyond you that it fails spectacularly or dismally; unless your intent is humor, sarcasm, witticism or plonk. So given you have an idea you have thought well about and want to write about; who is your intended audience:preschoolers, skateboarders, politicians, cosmologists…? Ok, so you have thought and thought very well about quarks and black holes-what do you want to say to who? Writing well starts with thinking well; then as a wall builder who has experience and knowledge-moves on with construction. Wrong foundation, wrong materials, wrong procedure and steps leads to wall collapse-so to with a sentence, letter, journal entry or book. All parts are necessary to get cohesion-staying power, support and finished product-be that wall, sentence story or book. Suggestion: read, read, talk, think-repeat, repeat-then get good support to write your book. Good luck.

I want to be a writer, what is the first step? Do you write with your feet? ::: From the usual development of a child, we can learn from teachers and parents as to how to get used to the letters of the alphabet and how to write these down and keep writing these down till we become ready, willing and able to respond to what is required of us in the School lessons. Homework is usually the way we learn to develop a more free attitude towards the use of words and descriptions and characterisations, too. I remember the required essay on the MY DIARY experiences. This chore was forced upon the class and we ploughed our way through the usual ways to stretch out the words across each line. We had no desire to relate our boring days to our teacher. Just a few words on each line was my way of rebelling against this chore. However, as I approached the last years of Junior School, I learnt enough to give my Headmaster something to think about. He set the class a task we’d never encountered before. We were to describe a piece of music that he played for us. It was lively and forceful. I described what I felt was happening and he wandered around the class to see what was being written. When he saw how furiously I was writing, he was amazed. At the end of the task, he chose my words to be read out to the class. That wasn’t my intent, as I was only trying to please him. The rest of the class wasn’t even on my mind. At a later time, when I was keenly interested in poetry, I had a book that outlined different writing styles for poems. I came across a poem called YOU BID ME TRY. This was about a poet being challenged to write a poem. So he wrote it in a special poetry style, one I’d never even have considered. I was interested in the way that the poet was enthusiastic, rather than merely showing off. He was pleasing an audience of one and yet eventually his words were to be included in the book I held in my hands at that time. It was as if I had been guided to it. It was as if I had been encouraged to write on the spot like he had done. I remember others who could do this. Famous songwriter Sammy Cahn could write songs one after another. He explained this in his autobiography, I SHOULD CARE. I was interested in writing songs and also came across Sammy’s Rhyming Dictionary for songs. He explained how he had memorised hundreds of songs. I’ve written hundreds of songs, too, yet can only remember a few, in part, just snatches of the words yet more often I can remember various tunes. I lived in the times of the Beatles and Brit Pop was really on top as far as I was concerned. So I became aware of different music styles and performances. I could appreciate great singers as well as those who read poems that had been set to music. When it came to writing songs, I checked the libraries for further advice and found it quite easily. I gained from such advice and continued writing for years. One day, I realised that the names of the girls I fell in love with kept changing, while the lovey-dovey romantic phrases remained the same. I fell out of love with love songs and very soon I stopped being involved with songs. Only rarely writing some new song. I concentrated on poetry from then on. I am sharing my thoughts about my experiences because my writing journey has spanned decades and rarely have I received enough money to make any sense out of being a writer at all. So I wouldn’t advise anybody to become a writer. It’s like a vocation as if you become an unpaid evangelist. You share what’s on your mind or what’s come to mind. Many writers can begin a brand new story or poem and get somewhere with these so much so they become established writers. Their works regarded highly, money coming in and so on. Most of us invest our time and money yet without a fair reward for doing so. It’s sometimes called vanity publishing since publishers exist to share both the brilliant and the average. They make money, we don’t. Even so, should we choose to become writers, there are writing classes we can attend and learn what’s what and what’s not. We can progress just by studying punctuation and so on and on and on. We can use Internet resources like the grammarly-dot-com error checking for our documents and even store a copy online after checking and revising the text. We can use free images for our web sites and blogs and other interests. We can benefit from web sites like unsplash-dot-com and pixabay-dot-com as well as favourite images found on pinterest-dot-com or Google search results. So we won’t be as limited as previous generations were. My concern is towards creating poetry I can help others read easily the very first time. I keep editing a new poem and read it several times to get the phrases working well. I recommend using a computer so as to create different versions during the writing and editing times. title1a.rtf and title1b.rtf to start off with and then continuing with further name changes to identify the updated versions. You know, like switching lines or verses around to create a better flow. The initial draft is up for grabs. It isn’t considered the be all and end all of the new poem. What matters is not the writing but the dedication to getting a finished product. It may depend on the intended audience but the Internet users grab what we write and use it elsewhere. I wrote a poem about Wonder Woman saying how lovely she was and later found the same poem being used on another web site praising the beauty of cats and kittens. Some of my Stephen Gayford poems have been used by English Literature teachers to develop their students to appreciate poetry and the way it was written, what descriptions were employed, characterisations and whether the poem had a pleasant or inspiring conclusion. Maybe a funny poem was chosen, such as I AM AN ELEPHANT! In any case, my 2,300+ poems are on the poemhunter-dot-com website. These may be downloaded as a complete collection in the form of a PDF file. I update some poems every now and then and save the updated collection to make that available instead. Many of the poemhunter poems are found elsewhere on various poetry collections and poetry databases. So a Google search can find these if the titles are known. That’s how I found my poems on other websites and PDF files, too. All of this info is to explain a journey so that others can see that money isn’t the chief concern. It’s basically being called to be a writer in some fashion, for a general purpose or just becoming a dabbler, not restricting ourselves to just one course of action. I can write poems and poems, various poetry styles, songs, stories and parables. I can imitate how others would sing songs or recite poems. I can imagine how an actor would portray such words if sharing the text on YouTube and it’s no big deal. Many children can do what the adults would do. It’s all about being dedicated enough to follow whatever talents exist or may yet exist. It’s like Smallville, the TV series, in which Clark Kent learns how to develop his range of superpowers, even to the point that he can fly like Supergirl. We see how he can use super strength and supervision and micro vision, too. He is even equipped with Kryptonian instincts that are superior to here on Earth. A writer follows ideas and develops instincts, learning to listen to phrases that come as thoughts that are meant to spark more than an interest for just a few seconds. So a title can lead to a poem, a song or a story. If not followed, it remains as it was. To become a writer is nothing new. The themes remain the same as before. Either fact or fantasy. Either basic or complex. The language kept simple or deliberately eloquent. But is the writer just playing with words for personal pleasure or trying to please a few educated minds or reaching out to try to help Mankind? Complex words? Yeah, great, super, wonderful, marvellous, but not meant for one and all. Remember, the people aren’t going to send us loadsa money. Poetry and poverty aren’t just words that are close to each other in the dictionary. But sell just one pop song and you can buy a house. If that’s all you require from being a writer, then good luck with that. The other end of the scale is living as a writer and dying as a martyr because of the importance of what you write and believe. The Christian apostles lived for Jesus and died for Jesus, all because of the promise of Heaven. If there’s no opposition to what each of us may write, then maybe we aren’t effective writers after all. If we don’t make other writers jealous of what we can do, then maybe we ain’t all we think we are. But… if we truly know we’re meant to write and to keep writing, then what on Earth is it that we’re REALLY meant to be writing about? What will stand the test of time? What will prove of profit to Mankind, not just our bank accounts? And are we willing to count the cost and to pay the cost? Imagine the pens and the papers, the computers and the printers, the cost of Broadband and the hours spent just checking our emails… then the checking of errors in the text, the updating of current events, facts and figures and so on. I tell you, there are days when the computer drives me crackers, when the poems just don’t work right, when ideas get rejected or overlooked or sabotaged. It’s no wonder that any success is regarded as a miracle! PRAISE THE LORD!

Establish your goal. What does it mean to “be a writer,” what exactly to you want to write, and what do you want to achieve? I recommend setting goals you have control over, that don’t rely on other people. As an example, “write 100 novels” is better than “write 10 bestsellers,” because you can’t make people buy your books.Read a lot and write even more. If you read inside your genre you can see all the things they are doing that you need to do, and also what they aren’t doing that can make you stand out. Outside your genre, you can pick up tricks to help round out your writing. Reading is important, but you can’t call yourself a writer if you don’t write. There are a lot of people out there talking about writing and tweeting about writing and setting up their perfect writer’s nook and messing around with fonts, but they aren’t writing.Learn to write poorly. Everyone does by accident, but an inexperienced writer gets stuck and won’t write anymore until they get that part right, while the experienced writer keeps going.Get educated. There’s an aura of charming authenticity around the self taught artist, and it’s a lie. There are thousands of artists who have gone down your path, fallen into mistakes and successes, and now offer insights. You’re a fool if you don’t take them up on it. You will get much farther, much faster with a systematic knowledge of the craft.Be discerning in where you accept advice, and take responsibility for your own journey.

Find a quiet spot in your house, at the mall, anywhere. Turn off your smart phone. Take off your earpods, earphones, headphones. No interruption for the next exercise… Place your laptop in front of you. Place your hands on the keyboard. Or grab a nice pen, open an empty notebook, and put the pen on the paper. And for the next TEN minutes, write WITHOUT STOPPING. Make a deal with yourself that unless there is an earthquake, fire, or that kind of emergency that would jeopardize your life, you will NOT leave your seat, and your hand will NOT stop. Just keep writing. If you do not know what to write, keep writing the sentence “I do not know what to write” over and over again until SOMETHING ELSE starts to emerge and whispers its presence. Then start to write that and keep going. This is an exercise to punch through the inertia and writer’s block that prevents many beginning writers from starting to write anything. And read this magnificent book to learn how you can take that first step to write (from which the above writing exercise is taken): “Writing Down the Bones: Freeing the Writer Within” by Natalie Goldberg Good luck!

By writing a lot. Everyone I know or have heard of who is a writer (professional, amateur, etc) got that way by writing a lot.  First you write a lot of crap.  Then you write a bunch of stuff that is slightly less crappy.  Then you keep writing, and maybe most of it still sucks.  After many, many years of doing this, you become a decent writer.  Then you keep on writing.  You must write for 10,000 hours before you achieve mastery, which is the threshold at which someone might actually want to publish you. It helps if you have people who tell you how much and exactly how you suck, but you have to be willing to listen to them: In writing workshops, the rule is that you are not allowed to talk (in particular, defend) when other people are discussing and criticizing your writing.  This is an especially good mindset to develop so that you can set aside your natural reaction to ego-wounding and learn to accept criticism in order to improve. In summary, the steps to becoming an author are:  Write a lot.When you get criticism about your writing, focus on figuring out how it is valid, rather than how it is invalid.Keep writing a lot.In between all that, it might be useful to have some interesting life experiences.

Answer the following questions to yourself: Do you love to talk?Do you like to listen to speech?Do you have your opinions on many things?Do you like to read?Do you find understanding new things interesting?Do you think language and literature are nice? Any language for that matter?Do you have patience with any hobby?Do you forgive yourself of little and big mistakes?If your answer is yes to these questions, you can be a writer. Once this is done, start rewriting sentences from any text for five minutes each day. Start simplifying complex things you read on a paper. Read for thirty minutes every day. Does not matter what you read. Write your journal or diary or start a blog and be random about what you write and cross-check your grammar with an online grammar checker tool. In three months of regular practice, you are ready to start writing. Whether you want to join one of the professional writing charters in any organization - Technical Writing, Product Writing, Business Writing, Patent Writing, Instructional Writing, Content Writing, Creative Writing, Legal Writing, Research Writing, Academic Writing - or you want to write a book, you are ready to start off your learnings on the respective domains. All the best.

This was my path: Subscribe to THE WRITER magazine for at least two full years. Read the best-selling writers in the genre/niche you want to occupy as a writer. Read voraciously in all areas so you can begin to notice the honored writers versus the hacks and recognize the difference in quality. Read books about copy (sales) writing. Even if you don’t want to become a copywriter, you will learn extremely valuable lessons about how to write riveting stories that keep people glued to the page. (In grade and high school, teachers teach us to write pleasantly and properly; they don’t usually teach us how to wrote powerfully, because most aren’t professional writers themselves; they’re technicians: grammarians, sentence diagram experts, spell checkers, etc., little of which is the silver bullet to proficient, professional un-put-down-able writing.) (Great writers frequently break the rules that teachers teach!) Write, write, and write some more. Make it not just a habit, but an addiction! As Mark Twain said (I’m paraphrasing here), “If you want to learn to write, write for three years. If no one offers you money after that investment of time and effort, find something else to do.” (He was a little more crass than this, ending with, “…ditch-digging is what you were meant to do.”) Have someone who recognizes adept writing look over what you write (perhaps join a writers’ group in your area headed by a professional writer, or hire a professional copywriter or editor) and critique it to find spots where it can be improved.

My knowledge of subjects outside of writing is what got me my job as a writer. Upcoming writers need to think about how their perspective is different from the competition. If your plan is to go to college and get a degree in English like everyone else, it might be wise to take the path less traveled. It’s much easier to get a job writing for a periodical for magicians than it is getting a job writing for Forbes or the New Yorker. Share your work. You need to get feedback on your work so that you can get better. I can’t understand why young writers don’t share their writing. You may want to start by taking your favorite TV show, movie, or book, and write a little fanfiction on it. You can use the author’s (or director’s) characters so you don’t have to make your own, and then add a very simple (or complex, depending on what you’re willing to do) plot line. Have the characters go through the plot using your own words and dialogue. It doesn’t have to be your best work, but you should be able to work your way up to being able to add your own characters, world, and system, until finally it turns out to be your own story. (And by system I mean magic system or physics system, where magic or physics act the way you want them to; such as: (For Physics System: You may want to have it where the planet you start your story on doesn’t have as strong gravity as the real world so you research and make sure that the inhabitants of your planet jump really high or everything falls slower, etc. (For Magic System: Pretty much the same as the Physics System, except there would be no research involved. You can have people be able to shoot fire from their hands or whatever, but you make limits to what they can do.

I’m going to break this down into some easy steps: Establish a routine, share with your friends, revise according to criticism, seek professional help, share with the community, and make bank. 1. Establish the routine. Regardless of whether you write out what you want to write about or if you just write to discover what you want to write about, you’re going to want to find a way to keep yourself writing. I know some of you have high stress jobs, and you just don't have the willpower after work to write after work. You might have to write like crazy on the weekend. You might have to write before you go to work or make writing part of your de-stressing routine. De-stressing not distressing. The important part is that whatever you decide, you’re going to want to keep in consistent. Sit down with the same cup of coffee, tea, or whatever your poison, in your house, with your laptop, with a pad of paper, your inkwell and quill, or your typewriter. Once you have yourself set up, spend the entire allotted time to writing. Worry about research later, outside of your writing time, as if you worry about details, you’re going to spend the whole time researching, or God forbid, watching adorable cat videos. 2. Share with your Friends If you don’t have friends yet, it’s time to make some. A good way to do it is to look up some acquaintances from high school. Say, hey, it’s your old pal from high school, I finished writing this story and wanted to know what you thought of it. People hate reading. They’ll often talk about things they’ve read in high school, but it’ll be like pulling out toe-nails to get them to read your work. If it’s been a week and you haven’t heard anything on twenty pages, just poke them and say, hey, have you finished reading my piece yet? (They would have told you if they did, so it’s clear they didn’t). Say, it would mean a lot to me if you did. If you could just read it until it gets boring and let me know where that first boring part is, it would be a great help! Don’t contact them again unless they message you first—you already tried once, and you don’t want to become obnoxious. My personal advice is don’t share the same piece with the same person. If they read it once, then chances are you didn’t respond to every piece of advice that they gave you. Share it with the next person instead, and see where those pieces of advice intersect. If they say to change the same thing, chances are that you need to change it. 3. Revise according to Criticism So you see all the places that people have told you to change things—it’s going to be hard because they’ll tell you large swathes of work are boring that you need to be there out of technicality. Let’s just try to listen to them for once. Don’t change the things that are absolutely essential for the piece, but all other things, let them be up for grabs. You can always go back to the original piece if you don’t end up liking how things turn out. Give it some time. When you first write it, you had a good experience writing it and remember the very act of creation being a good one. Looking back at what you created in a week, a month, or even a year can be an eye-opening experience. What you wrote in a flurry of inspiration is riddled with typos, you clearly just rewrote a sitcom that you watched earlier in the week, and you tried to do an accent, just because you haven’t done accents before, and it’s some fake country accent that anybody would quickly deride. Correct the errors, change it to be original, and take out that accent—or maybe ask somebody with an accent to proof it for you—hey that could work! 4. Seek Professional Help Seriously, get help. You can send your work off to a professional novelist who advertises for helping with manuscripts. You can join a writing class in your local community. Attend a big writing conference where authors talk about writing like AWP. In addition to that, you’re going to want to read craft books. Not arts and crafts, of course, I’m talking about serious books by authors talking about how to write well in your genre, whether you’re writing poetry, screenplays, novels, or video games, you’re going to want to see how the best do it. Now lastly, if you’re loaded with money—you might consider a bachelor’s in Creative Writing, followed by an MFA. It’s not for everyone, but what you can learn from a close mentor and peers will forward your writing in what you would do on your own by about ten years experience, if you do what you’re supposed to—like you actually read the books, do the exercises, and respond well to criticism. If you’re unwilling to do any of those things, then maybe the schooling just isn’t for you. You can always do all your own reading and arrive at some very well written stories if you're particularly talented and have good taste. 5. Share with the Community I think at this point, you’ve written your novel or a handful of short stories. You’ve revised. Maybe you’ve gone through school. Some of your peers are saying that your work is ready for publication, as in it’s as good as it’s going to be. There are some who would suggest immediately that you ought to self-publish. Although it’s a viable path to take, you’ve put far too much work into writing to take the back-path now. You’re going to want to make a listing of all the publications that you want your work to be in. Yours might look a little bit different than others. At the very top, you’ll want to have the notable publications—for me, that would be the well known magazines like the New Yorker, the Atlantic Monthly, Harper’s, and so on. Check to see their submission guidelines, read some of their issues to know what you’re submitting to, and write a good cover letter saying a little bit about yourself and what you like about the magazine. Chances are, you will get a rejection notice or you won’t receive anything back and after the allotted time, you know your story is ready to submit to somewhere else. Save your rejection notices and look for any positive feedback that you might receive. Often times, you’ll have standard pre-written responses for rejection, but look for ones that deviate from the standard response. If you couldn’t tell yet, this is a long, patient process. You might look then for notable online publications, regional magazines, university magazines, or small publications. Look for what pays, look for what agents are reading, and look for what has a larger reader-base. I like to look at where the big awards are being pulled from like the O’Henry prize stories. You’ll be more likely to win such prizes if you’re being read in those same publications. As you can imagine, this will require a little research on your end of things. 6. Make Bank A joke. I hope you weren’t expecting to make any money off of this. Daniel J. Dupuy +JMJ+

Grab a copy of Writer's Digest from your local book store or magazine rack and start reading. Every issue will help you with some aspect of your writing. Pay attention to the WRITING parts as well as the BUSINESS parts. That kills most new writers faster than a bad review. LEARN the BUSINESS of writing. Next, read. Read everything on everything. Learn how experienced writers use language to express their thoughts, emotions, and ideas. Read dime store crap, and the greatest novels in western civilization. Read it all. Read every night before you go to bed. Next, learn your craft. Take courses and study the use of grammar and language. Take a poetry class. Yea, boring as heck, but true poetry (not this modern stuff) will teach you how to use language to paint a scene. And get a word a day calendar. You need to know a lot of words if you are going to be using them. And be sure your classes are taught by tight-a$$es. You want hard critiques of your work. This is the time to learn, not be pampered. If you just want to be pampered then give your stories to your mom. She'll kiss you on the forehead and put your story on the refrigerator. But no one else will ever see them. Finally, write. That's right, write. Everyone wants to be a writer, but no one wants to do the work involved. If you want to be a writer then you have to write something every day. Write about anything, but write. Good luck.

If you want to be a writer and to join the worst paid, the worst treated, and least rewarding profession of all, I suggest that you start out with the Door Test to discover if you really want to endure the life of a writer. The Door Test is a very simple procedure: Open a door that has two handles, one on each side.Grab a door handle with each hand so you are facing the edge of the door.While holding onto the handles within eighteen inches or so (or half a meter) of your body, bend forward with great force, causing your head to collide with the edge of the door. Do it with sufficient force to create severe pain and dizziness.Repeat steps one, two, and three until you are rendered unconscious.Upon recovery, if you still want to be a writer, repeat steps one through four, or stab yourself with a knitting needle.If you still want to be a writer, check yourself into a mental hospital.On the other hand, if you are very rich and don’t have to work, do whatever you want, but understand that writing will bring you nothing but rejection, humiliation, and disappointment.

Recently, I've been thinking of a quote/adage I picked up back in university: "Writers write. Authors edit." If anyone can attribute that back to a source, please feel free to leave me the citation in a comment.  Now, I'm extrapolating your question to mean "good author" or "known author." The designation "published author" is easy to achieve with modern self-publishing, but huge tracts of self-published worked are clearly first drafts.  To be a "good" author - "good" being very subjective of course - you need to edit, especially with your audience in mind. If you're writing fiction, refine it to the greatest impact. If you're writing non-fiction, then make sure it is clear, concise, and easy to read. Whatever you write, make sure it's the best it can be. And always get feedback. You don't have to agree with your feedback, but you need some. You may be Hemingway in your own mind, but there's no guarantee others will agree unless you ask them. Ask friends who are willing to be honest and who like your genre of writing. Don't ask your mother. If you don't know anyone personally, there are online communities that critique each other's work. Check out Critters Writers Workshop, for example. Make edits based on the critiques if you feel it improves your work.  But if all you want is to see your name in print, sign up for any of a host of ebook publishing platforms: Kindle, Barnes and Noble, Kobo, iBooks, Smashwords, and so on. Write something and put it up. It's just that simple.

The first thing you need to really understand is that writing is not a goal, but a journey. You never reach the end. Do some reading. What do you like about certain authors’ writing styles? How can you incorporate their styles into yours? Do not write like them; write like you, using their techniques to enhance your style. Before you start, you must be adept with the tools of the trade: spelling, grammar, punctuation, etc. Unless you know how to use the tools, your work will be crap. You need a story (easy part), then you need to develop the story (hard part). Almost every book is about people facing challenges, overcoming obstacles, being fallible and human. Stay away from superheroes unless you can make them believable. Have a plot, a story arc. Place yourself inside the story and write it from there. Become intimate with your characters, scenes, dialog, the period when the story takes place, and everything that will end up on your pages. Never believe your first draft will be a winner. It will suck, believe me. That’s okay. Edit, re-edit, and re-re-edit until your work is smooth and compelling. Enlist the help of others to critique your work. Join a writer’s group. The opinions of others can be worth its weight in gold. Get your book professionally edited. It will be worth it. Oh yes, if you think you’re going to make a million with your first book, forget it! Be grateful to be able to afford a pizza every month with your winnings. That is reality. Still, writing is like fishing: you’re always hoping to catch the “big one” and you’re willing to do what it takes to make it possible with the right hooks and enticing bait. Believe in yourself and never give up.

Accept that your writing is not going to come out perfectly. It may not even come out close to what you wanted it to. That doesn’t mean it’s not great! But if you go in expecting to be perfect from the get-go, you’ll probably end up giving up in dismay/anger in a few months.Read a lot. Write more.Figure out whether you prefer to plan or just start writing and see what happens. Most people end up somewhere along this spectrum. (Personally, I like to write out a very basic plan with plot points to hit, and then start writing and do my best to keep to those points, but if I stray it’s not a big deal.)Keep writing. That’s the only way to be sure you’ll improve. Courses, tips, tricks - they can be useful, but the only surefire way to get better at writing is to keep writing.A good technique is to try “free-writing” if you haven’t already. All you do is sit down in front of an empty page of a notebook or empty word document, set a timer (usually for five, ten or twenty minutes) and then write whatever pops into your head. Doesn’t have to be a story. Just write. It loosens you up and can surprise you with the creativity you prompt in yourself.

First of all, why do you want to be a writer? And secondly, why do you want to write ‘a book’? Because trust me… you probably don’t even know what the real job is about. That’s the reason why, if we are talking about writing novels, I disagree with the previous answers. 1) you should start with ‘scenes’. Scenes are incomplete parts of a SINGLE plot. Until you can’t master the art of writing good scenes trying to write ‘a book’ is entirely useless. 2) you should then start trying to master the art of writing ‘short tales’ because if you can’t master the art of writing a short tales trying to write a book is entirely useless. 3) you should then start trying to become a good writer at writing descriptions. Creating a image inside the reader’s mind is extremely difficult but, sometimes, you just need it. As a matter of facts, it’s more a matter of choosing what to describe NOT. Descriptions are the most difficult part of writing and yet, you should do your best to become a decent writer at writing desciptions anyway. 4) you should then start trying to become proficient with characters development, because when writing a novel, you spend much more time with your characters rather than when you write a short tale and you must build them up much more seriously then the way you are used to do. Points 1–4 are just the first and biggest parts of the creative process only. Beginners usually focus on the creative process only as if style was a non-existing problem. On the other side, for me introducing you to the basics of style would require me to write here a full book, so I won’t even start indroducing you the main points. On the contrary, I will give you just a a single one million dollar advice: In order to become a good writer, you have to be a bad writer first. Take your favourite writers,ok? Now take the one of them who has the simpliest style of them all. Take something you wrote in the past and compare your stile to the style of this very famous writer. If you honestly don’t see where his style is far, far, far better then yours, and you see a difference in terms of ‘content-only’… Congratulations! You are a bad writer, and now you know it. You are so ignorant about your job that you can’t even see how his style is better then yours. Now you know it. A good beginner is able to see how much his style sucks compared to famous writers. As a matter of facts, it usually takes years just to start ‘seeing’ it. That’s the reason why I use to say that to become a good writer, you have to be a bad one first.
