Don’t be afraid to suck: A lot of writers (and a lot of other people who try other things) get discouraged due to the fact that the stuff they’re writing is terrible at the start, and then they give up because they can’t do anything good. That’s not going to get you anywhere. Just because your stuff sucks now doesn’t mean it’ll suck forever, and you have to suck before you can be any good, unless you were born as some writing prodigy or something. Also, the first draft of everything is terrible, even novels written by professional, highly skilled writers. It’s a universal rule.Write because you enjoy it: You might have heard of people talking about writing like it’s some kind of “artistic struggle” and how it’s “painful” to get the words out. Someone once said “Writing is easy. You sit at a typewriter and open a vein.” The writer’s struggle is a farce, or at least I hope it is, because if this many writers are torturing themselves we kind of have a problem. You should write because it’s fundamentally enjoyable, not out of some painful artistic obligation. You wouldn’t play soccer for the feeling of grass burns on your knees, so why would you write for the feeling of mental torture? Just let loose and have some fun.Read a lot: Strong writers are also strong readers, because they learn from the material they read. You’ll do yourself a disservice if you only read one genre, but it is important to read lots of books in the genre you’re writing - for example, if you’re writing fantasy, read lots of fantasy, both good and bad, but also mix some other genres in there to keep your worldview wide. Books on writing are also really helpful, both for theory’s sake and for learning practical skills.

Someone else might introduce me as “an author” but I never call myself that. I might say that have authored some novels, but I’d be far more likely to say (if I’m asked, especially in a social situation) that I have written some books, or even say that I have had some published, but the word “author” as a self-descriptive makes me cringe because to me, it sounds like the user is putting on airs. Because I write fiction, I most often describe myself as a novelist. But however you label yourself, before you can claim the status of author, I think you need to be published.

Look around you. No, serious. Just look around and find inspiration. Books, games, life as a whole- something’s going to make you want to write something down. Or you could always dream and think, criticize or question something that’s already there. I got into writing like that- read too many copy-paste plot lines and decided “if this is all it takes to be a New York Times Best Seller, I could do it.” Writing really is about a first question. “What if this happened instead of that?” “What if this existed or this didn’t?” And my personal favorite: “How can I make people hate me yet want to keep reading?” Once you get that first idea, that first question, keep going. “But for that to happen, what would need to lead up to it, and what’s the outcome?” Don’t stop asking questions, and you’ll eventually have a plot and character outlines. Then it’s just a matter of fleshing out the story with your own voice.

I’m assuming you’re asking about writing fiction, though I guess my advice is true for non-fiction as well. First of all, What A J Kohler (below) says is spot on. If your English (or whatever language you’re planning to write in) skills are lacking, you can’t write a readable book. The rule I remember hearing that really made sense to me is that you can’t break the rules (and every genre has rules) unless you know them, so polish your grammar, your spelling, your sentence and paragraph construction. Learn what makes dialogue work and the tenets of storytelling. If you’re comfortable with your skills, you need to figure out what you want to write and read in that genre. I have always loved romances, mainly because one of the tropes of the genre is that there has to be a happy, or at the very least, satisfactory, ending for the protagonists. Before I ever wrote a word, I read a lot of romances, figured out which authors appealed to me and used their style as a rough guideline for my own work. I wrote my first book, one that will never see the light of day, but it taught me that I could finish a book, that I knew how to write a beginning, a middle, and an end, and I learned things in the process of writing it that gave me the confidence to seriously pursue a career as an author. I joined Romance Writers of America where I attended panels and workshops with authors whose books I had read and enjoyed, and the networking at conferences proved to be more valuable even than the workshops. I met editors, publishers, production people, but most important, I met other authors. I’m not sure how it is in other genres, but I’ve found the community of romance authors to be amazingly helpful with those of us learning our way. The policy of paying it forward is alive and well with so many of the wonderfully talented folks I’ve met over the past twenty or so years, and many of them have helped me, and continue to help me, as my career ebbs and flows as so many do. My 67th book was just published last week, and I’m currently working to bring out some of my reverted titles. I guess my best advice to new writers would be to know the language, read the kinds of books you hope to write, and then write something that’s totally different. It doesn’t take long for a writer to discover their voice, that manner of throwing words together that’s entirely their own, but you have to write a lot of words to find that personality in your work. So the best advice I can give you is to write. Set aside time every day to put words on paper (or on a screen!) but don’t give up. And, as AJ Kohler said, don’t quit the day job. That comes after you’ve established yourself as an author. Best of luck to you.

I “got started” more than fifty years ago as a university student, when I volunteered to write book and movie reviews for the campus student newspaper. That let me build up a clippings book that I could take to a newspaper and look for a job as a part-time “stringer,” covering municipal council meetings in Greater Vancouver. That led to the newspaper assigning me feature stories to write, as well as a more or less constant beat to cover anything that happened on campus. Eventually, I was taken on as summer staff. That gave me enough experience to get a job as news editor on a suburban weekly, then editor of a weekly tabloid on Vancouver Island. That led to a job offer to be assistant to a newly elected Member of Parliament, where I discovered I had a natural knack for writing speeches. I then spent more than forty years as a speechwriter, mostly freelancing. Could a beginner follow the same path today? Probably not. Journalism now requires a degree. In my day, it required the ability to write news copy and to know what the important part of a story was, so you could ask the right questions. But my approach might still work on small-town newspapers, although they seem to be shrinking and drying up. Or get that journalism degree. Journalism can still lead to several different writing career options.

You can start with a detailed outline or skip it completely. I tend to be somewhere in the middle, with a loose outline of where the story’s going. I don’t get into the details too much because I like to make things up as I go. It adds an element of fun to the process for me. But everyone’s different in how they plan (or don’t). Beyond that, you write. You stubbornly write every day. Set a number of words you are determined to write every day or block out a chunk of your day—every day at the same time—when you’ll commit to distraction-free writing. The first draft will be a chaotic mess. There will be plot holes and all kinds of “junk” in there. Don’t worry about it. While you write, the editor/critic in you needs to be on vacation. Just write and write and write with abandon. Clean up the mess later.

I'd suggest you start at the beginning. Walk outside and look at something, a tree, a bird or maybe a building. Write one quick sentence about it. Read the sentence and then rewrite it with more detail, more exact descriptive words. When finished, edit it. Take away unnecessary words, innacurate words. When you're done, put it into a paragraph and again go through the same process. This won't make you a better writer instantly, but if you're unwilling to try, you may not be ready to try and write. Everyone will tell you to read, and you should. But you must read actively. How does the author use language? How does she vary sentence length and structure? Are characters flat or are they three dimishional? Did the writing evoke some emotion? Study the craft. Read on Writing by Stephen King and Bird by Bird by Anne Lamont. There are tons of good books on the skills of writing. Good luck

The first step to approach anything is by getting to know the science behind it and understanding the nuances. To elaborate, you must be clear about How’s and Why’s. Be a voracious Reader. - This is the trainee/novice step. Read for hours and just read like a madman. Read like never before. Read novels, newspapers, articles, online articles and everything around you. Beginning days will be painful, but once you get hold of the grammar and language flow, it will be fun. The more you read, the better you will develop as a writer.Jot down important points. - After the training is done, its time to sharpen the skill. Take a article, read it and jot down important points. This will create a mapping in your brain about the structure of an article. This step might take time but it will be worth.Try composing small articles - This is the “Implementation step”. Once you’re abreast of the structure, sentence formation and language flow and usage of tenses, its time you chose a random topic of your interest and write a 500 word article on it. Proofread it at least thrice and make it even better. Now, ask a friend, senior, father or someone to read it and provide their review comments. Now, is the point where you need to repeat the 3rd step over and over till the day you are a fantabulous writer.Practice heavily to minimise mistakes and improve on language flow and sentence coherency. Well, I myself am not a Writer but these above steps I believe will improve your overall understanding and writing skills as it has done mine. Hope this helps!

You have to be patient and hopeful even when all publishers are rejecting your manuscript, or when the book sales are dropping.You should have a brave heart because the journey of a writer has its fair share of tears and heartbreaks, be it rejections or negative reviews.

You write a book.  This is not a joke answer. There are no other criteria. You do not need to be published. You do not need to be any good. One of the most useful things a writer who is just starting can do is learn to read mindfully. Also read critically: was it really necessary, when a character walked into a room, to freeze-frame that scene and describe everything in sight? One tip I give beginning writers in my university and online courses is to recognize and eliminate forms of the verb “to be”. Those forms include “is”, “are,” “was,” and “were.” Why? These are dead verbs. They don’t provide any images in readers minds. For example, if I yell at you “Was!”, what comes to your mind? Nothing. But if I yell “Run! Fire!”, you know to run away from a fire in the vicinity. Replace dead verbs with strong verbs (verbs that provide images to readers) as often as you can. I’ve seen more growth in beginning writers from this one tip than anything else I’ve taught. A few years ago I collected up this tip, and 6 other common writing problems into this online course with exercises and lessons: 7 Lessons for Becoming a Standout Writer.
